Graphical abstract Modulation of geometric and electronic structures of electrocatalysts, adjustment of operational parameters, and regulation of system configurations have significant effects on the selective production of liquid oxygenates by electrocatalytic CO2 reduction. Electrocatalytic CO2 reduction (ECR) to produce value-added fuels and chemicals using renewable electricity is an emerging strategy to mitigate global warming and decrease reliance on fossil fuels. Among various ECR products, liquid oxygenates (Oxys) are especially attractive due to their high energy density, high safety and transportability that could be adapted to the existing infrastructure and transportation system. However, efficiently generating these highly reduced oxygen-containing products by ECR remains challenging due to the complexity of coupled proton and electron transfer processes. In recent years, in-depth studies of reaction mechanisms have advanced the design of catalysts and the regulation of reaction systems for ECR to produce Oxys. Here, by focusing on the production of typical Oxys, such as methanol, acetic acid, ethanol, acetone, n-propanol, and isopropanol, we outline various reaction paths and key intermediates for the electrochemical conversion of CO2 into these target products. We also summarize the current research status and recent advances in catalysts based on their elemental composition, and consider recent studies on the change of catalyst geometry and electronic structure, as well as the optimization of reaction systems to increase ECR performance. Finally, we analyze the challenges in the field of ECR to Oxys and provide an outlook on future directions for high-efficiency catalyst prediction and design, as well as the development of advanced reaction systems. Keywords Electrocatalytic CO2 reduction Geometry and electronic structure Parameters and system configurations Liquid oxygenates 1 Introduction Using renewable energy to drive electrocatalytic CO2 reduction (ECR) for the production of fuels and chemicals is an effective strategy for building an artificial carbon circular economy, which can break our dependence on fossil resources as well as achieve the conversion of intermittent renewable energy into chemical energy for long-term and large-scale storage [1–4]. In recent years, ECR has been a rapidly expanding field of research and extensive work has been conducted to improve the selectivity and yield of the required products, with a particular focus on materials and device design [5–7]. Depending on the number of electrons transferred during the reaction, products such as formic acid (HCOOH), carbon monoxide (CO), methanol (CH3OH), methane (CH4), acetic acid (CH3COOH), ethylene (C2H4), ethanol (C2H5OH), propanol (C3H7OH), and others can be produced [8,9]. Among these products, highly reduced liquid oxygenates (Oxys) are especially attractive due to their high energy density, excellent safety and transportability that could be adapted to the existing infrastructure and transportation system [10,11]. For simplicity, in the following text, “Oxys” will represent deeply reduced liquid oxygenates except for formic acid. Compared to the well-established ECR systems for the production of formic acid, CO and C2H4, the selective production of Oxys is much more challenging. While numerous reviews exist on catalysts and device design for ECR, a comprehensive review dedicated to the mechanism and catalyst design aimed at enhancing Oxys production selectivity is conspicuously absent. The selective production of Oxys in ECR is a complex process that not only involves multi-proton coupled electron transfer, but also must compete with thermodynamically more favorable path for hydrocarbon generation. In addition to the persistent challenges in ECR, such as the high activation energy of CO2 and the competing hydrogen evolution reaction (HER) [12,13], careful regulation of reaction paths to avoid complete deoxygenation is also important [14,15]. Recent advances in our understanding of the fundamental principles of ECR have led to significant breakthroughs in the production of Oxys, such as alcohols [16–22], ketones [23,24], and acids [25–27]. This progress is attributed to catalysts design and the meticulous regulation of reaction systems. To facilitate future research, it is imperative to systematically summarize the most recent advances in this area. Therefore, by focusing on the typical C1 to C3 Oxys in ECR, we provide an exhaustive discussion of the reaction mechanism, principles of catalyst design and reaction microenvironment regulation for tuning ECR efficiency for Oxy production. A comprehensive summary of the current status of research and recent advances in catalysts, based on their elemental composition, is first provided, followed by a discussion of the different reaction paths and key intermediates for the electrochemical conversion of CO2 into Oxys. Recent studies aimed at improving the performance of ECR by the manipulation of catalyst geometry, electronic structure, and reaction systems regulation are then discussed. In addition, the techno-economic analysis and environmental implications of ECR are discussed. Finally, we highlight the persisting challenges and future prospects associated with selective Oxy production. 2 State-of-the-art research on ECR for Oxy production Oxys are chemical compounds with considerable commercial significance because of their vast market demand. They play a key role in organic synthesis, materials preparation, medicine, agriculture and fuels [28–30]. Their current industrial production relies mainly on fossil resources, consumes a large amount of energy and causes severe CO2 emission [31,32]. In comparison, ECR uses CO2 as the reactant to produce Oxys and can operate at ambient condition without excessive heat release [33]. This opens ways to mitigate carbon emissions and move the chemical industry towards carbon neutrality. However, the selective production of Oxys is challenging due to the general scaling relationship as well as the competitive deoxygenation paths that lead to the production of hydrocarbons. Suitable electrocatalysts that can lower the energy barriers for ECR and stabilize oxygen-containing intermediates in the multistep proton-assisted electron-transfer process are necessary. Before delving into the intricate reaction mechanism and principles of catalyst design, we first review current research status and advances in ECR catalysts for the production of typical C1 to C3 oxygenates based on their elemental composition. 2.1 Electrocatalysts for production of methanol from CO2 A diverse array of modern catalyst materials for methanol production by ECR is given in Fig. 1 . The inherent electronic characteristics of the individual elements are crucial to the adsorption of key intermediates at active sites, thereby having a significant impact on reaction selectivity [34]. Modifying the elemental composition of catalysts is the simplest and most effective approach to change the catalyst performance. We have classified the reported electrocatalysts for CO2 reduction to methanol into five categories based on the elemental composition of the catalytic active sites in the materials: Cu single-metal, non-Cu single-metal, Cu-based multi-metal, non-Cu multi-metal, and non-metal catalysts (Table S1, containing the full name and abbreviation of the catalyst in this section). In terms of selectivity and catalytic current density, Cu-based metal materials are currently the best catalysts for methanol production. Non-metallic boron phosphide is the only catalyst with over 90% methanol selectivity, but was achieved at extremely low current densities. In addition, non-Cu catalysts such as CoPc and Mo2C composite with carbon nanotubes generally exhibit methanol selectivity of around 80% at lower current densities. Overall, there are currently multiple catalysts that can achieve a selectivity of over 80% for electrocatalytic CO2 reduction to produce methanol, but the catalytic current density is generally low, below the commercial application standard of 200 mA cm−2. In the following, we will discuss in detail several representative methanol production catalysts. The majority of existing ECR catalysts for CH3OH production predominantly employ Cu-based materials, owing to the moderate CO binding capacity of the Cu surface. Nonetheless, the broad product distribution and the competing HER pose significant challenges in achieving highly selective production of methanol [35,36]. To increase methanol selectivity, extensive studies have been conducted on modifying the Cu catalysts by changing their composition and structure. These include nanoscale copper oxide [37], copper complexes [38], and oxide-derived copper [39]. For instance, Periasamy et al. used low-cost, stable Cu2O/Ppy particles with octahedral and microflower structures as a cathode to selectively reduce CO2 to methanol. This approach resulted in a FE of 93% ± 1.2% and a partial current density of 0.251 ± 0.02 mA cm−2 (Fig. 2 a, b) [40]. Research attention has also been directed to other transition metal compounds for ECR. Carbides, phosphides, and sulfides of Fe [41,42], Co [43], Mo [44], Ru [45], and Bi [46] have shown high methanol conversion performance. For example, Ji et al. developed a FeP nanoarray on Ti mesh (FeP NA/TM) as an efficient 3D catalytic electrode for ECR, achieving a high FECH3OH up to 80.2% and a partial current density of 2.5 mA cm−2 at −0.20 V vs. RHE in an H-cell (Fig. 2c, d) [42]. Zhang et al. synthesized a molybdenum carbide catalyst (Mo2C/N-CNT) that achieved 80.4% FE and a partial current density of 3.2 mA cm−2 for methanol at −1.1 V vs. SHE in a 0.1 M KHCO3 electrolyte and an H-cell (Fig. 2e, f) [44]. At present, the high FE of single metal catalyst is achieved at low current density, and it still faces challenges at high current density. This may be because the scaling relationships of *COOH, *CO, and *CHO intermediates on a single metal limit their activity in the reduction of CO2 to *CO and *CO to *CHO [47]. By introducing another metal element, there is a possibility for the increased interaction of active sites with *COOH or *CHO [3,48]. This interaction could preferentially stabilize these intermediates over *CO, thereby improving the selectivity of methanol. Bimetallic electrocatalyst systems have been extensively studied for their use in methanol production by ECR. The most common methods involve: (i) alloying with metallic Cu, such as Cu-Au [49], Pd x Cu y [12], Rh1Cu4 [50], CuGa2 [17] alloy electrocatalysts; and (ii) modification of copper oxide, including Cu2O/ZnO [51], Sn1/Vo-CuO-90 [52], Ag,S-Cu2O/Cu [13] electrocatalysts. As an example of alloying, Lu et al. developed a template-free self-assembly method to fabricate a Pd83Cu17 aerogel as an electrocatalyst for CO2 electroreduction, achieving an 80.0% CH3OH FE and a current density of 31.8 mA cm−2 with [Bmim]BF4 electrolyte at a low overpotential of 0.24 V (Fig. 3 a, b) [12]. As an example of modification of copper oxide, Sn atoms atomically dispersed and anchored on defective CuO catalysts, resulting in an impressive methanol FE of 88.6% at a high current density of 67.0 mA cm−2 (Fig. 3c, d) [52]. The superior performance of these electrocatalysts is attributed to the combined effect of another element and the copper support. For non-copper alloy catalysts, Payra et al. synthesized Pt x Zn/C (1 < x < 3) from metal-organic frameworks (MOFs) in which PtZn nanoalloys were immobilized on carbon, which had a high CH3OH FE of 81.4% at −0.90 V, surpassing the performance of PtZn/C and Pt3Zn/C catalysts [53]. The heterojunction nanoalloy interface in Pt x Zn/C could increase the onset potential of ECR. Currently reported non-copper alloy catalysts with high selectivity for methanol production often incorporate a Zn component. The reason for this is the lower H/O binding energy of Zn, which facilitates protonation of intermediates, desorption of oxygenated CH3O* intermediates, and avoids C–O bond cleavage and methane production. Additional non-metallic elements have been incorporated to create multi-metal oxide and sulfide electrocatalysts, e.g. Pd/SnO2 [54], CoO/CN/Ni [55], and Mo-Bi BMC [56]. For example, Wang et al. developed a CoO/CN/Ni ternary heterostructure electrocatalyst using cobalt oxide supported on N-doped nickel-based carbon [55]. Cobalt served as catalytic centers and significantly improved CH3OH production from CO2, resulting in a FE of 70.7%, with a j CH3OH value of 10.6 mA cm−2 at −0.7 V (Fig. 3e, f). The electronic state of the CoO/CN surface sites was mainly regulated by the underlying nickel that donated electrons to the outer CN, resulting in good catalytic performance for the reduction of CO2 to generate CH3OH. Non-metallic catalysts have gained widespread attention due to their low cost, the abundance of raw materials, environmental friendliness, and their ability not to release metal ions that could cause pollution during the electrocatalytic process. Non-metallic electrocatalysts also have a good performance in the field of ECR [57–62]. Mou et al. demonstrated the effective performance of boron phosphide nanoparticles as a non-metallic electrocatalysts in the reduction of CO2 to CH3OH [57]. The catalyst achieved a 92.0% FE in 0.1 M KHCO3 at −0.5 V, establishing it as one of the most efficient electrocatalysts reported for methanol production by ECR. This fine performance was mainly attributed to the combined effect of B and P, which increased the binding and activation of CO2 and reduced CO2 to CH3OH. 2.2 Electrocatalysts for production of acetic acid/acetate from CO2 Acetic acid is one of the valuable multi-carbon (C2+) products of ECR. It is widely used as the main component of vinegar, a food souring agent, a cleaning agent, as well as a key raw material for pharmaceuticals, pesticides, and other organic synthesis [25,63–66]. In industry, acetic acid is mainly synthesized through methanol carbonylation, which is a process of converting methanol and CO into acetic acid under the action of a catalyst. This traditional method is energy-intensive and considered environmentally unfriendly due to the amount of waste and emission generated during the process if fossil resource is used to obtain methanol and CO. The electrocatalytic reduction of CO2 for the synthesis of acetic acid presents a promising, environmentally-friendly, and carbon-neutral alternative to traditional synthetic methods [1,10,67]. Table S2 summarized recently reported works on acetic acid/acetate production through ECR and contained the full name and abbreviation of the catalyst in this section. It is important to note that only the one-step direct conversion of CO2 to acetic acid was included here, and the two-step process involving the initial conversion of CO2 to CO followed by the subsequent conversion of CO to acetic acid was not considered. The literature reveals a scarcity of reports on the one-step electrocatalytic reduction of CO2 to acetic acid. Most studies demonstrating high selectivity have been conducted in H-type electrolytic cells and at low current densities. The catalysts for acetic acid production were further categorized based on the composition of active site elements, as depicted in Fig. 4 . The following text provides a detailed discussion on several outstanding catalyst systems. The most common catalysts are copper-based ones, such as 3D dendritic copper-cuprous oxide composite reported by Zhu et al., which achieved a FE of 48% and a current density of 5.5 mA cm−2 [25]. Additionally, Li et al. developed a Cu/CuO x catalyst that, under a CO2(g) pressure of 58 atm, exhibited an impressive 87.3% FE for acetic acid and a current density of 86.3 mA cm−2 (Fig. 5 a, b) [27]. In addition to copper-based electrocatalysts, significant progress has also been made with other metal-based catalysts in directly converting CO2 to acetic acid/acetic salts. For instance, Genovese et al. demonstrated that nanostructured ironIII hydride on nitrogen-doped carbon can achieve a high FE of 61% for acetic acid production at a low potential of −0.5 V vs. Ag/AgCl (Fig. 5c, d) [68]. Furthermore, several molecular metal complexes have been developed for the direct reduction of CO2 to acetic acid/acetic acid salts [69,70]. Qiu et al. reported a 2D pccu-based covalent organic framework (COF) that reached a FE of 90.3% for acetate and a current density of 12.5 mA cm−2 (Fig. 5e) [26]. De et al. modified an MnIII-corrole complex with polyethylene glycol at three meta positions [69]. This catalyst produces acetic acid in a mildly acidic aqueous solution (pH = 6), achieving a FE of 63% for acetic acid (Fig. 5f). In current research, the activity and selectivity of single metal catalysts for ECR to acetic acid remain relatively low, making them insufficient to meet practical demands. However, they are well-suited for use as model catalysts to gain deeper insights into the reaction mechanisms, which may represent a promising avenue for future developments. The addition of another metallic element to Cu single-metal and Cu-based multi-metal catalysts can increase the selectivity of desired products by exploiting the combined effect of the different metals. Notably, bimetallic catalysts facilitate in-situ production and consumption of CO for acetic acid/acetate synthesis [64,65,71,72]. Silver is an ideal catalyst for reduction of CO2 to CO [73]. CO can be formed at silver sites and subsequently captured by adjacent Cu sites to form C–C bonds, thus promoting the production of acetate [8]. For instance, Wang et al. developed a method using ultra-small and monodispersed Cu and Ag bimetallic nanoparticles on thin poly-Fe(vbpy)3(PF6)2 films [64]. The electrode had a FE of 21.2% for acetate production at −1.33 V in 0.5 M KHCO3, when supplemented with 8 ppm benzotriazole at 0 °C (Fig. 6 a–c). Furthermore, Jin et al. reported a Cu-in-Ag dilute alloy catalyst that efficiently converted CO to acetate using electrical energy under high pressure (10 atm) reaction conditions [71]. The peak FE achieved was 91%, accompanied by an energy conversion efficiency of 34%. This represents approximately double the current record and offers up to 820 h of service life with an 80% FE retention (Fig. 6d–f). The investigation of non-metallic catalysts for the production of acetic acid/acetate by ECR has also attracted attention. A study by Liu et al. on an N-doped nanodiamond/Si rod array (NDD/Si RA) showed its potential as a non-metallic electrocatalyst for ECR [62]. This material had an efficient conversion of CO2 to acetate over formate, with an onset potential of −0.36 V, with the achieved FEacetate varying between 91.2% and 91.8% at voltages ranging from −0.8 to −1.0 V. In summary, significant breakthroughs have been made in the electrocatalytic reduction of CO2 to acetic acid through multimetallic strategies and modifications of reaction conditions. However, the catalytic activity and selectivity under ambient temperature and pressure remain relatively low, making it difficult to meet practical demands. Moreover, the products are often acetates, which introduces further challenges in acidification and separation, adding to manufacturing costs and limiting practical applications. Catalyst optimization combined with the solid electrolyte approach proposed by Wang et al. may be a promising direction for future research [74]. 2.3 Electrocatalysts for production of ethanol from CO2 Ethanol stands out as the most extensively studied Oxys produced by ECR, and its catalysts have been reported in the largest number of publications (Table S3, containing the full name and abbreviation of the catalyst in this section). In these studies, the selectivity of ethanol ranges from less than 10% to over 90%, while the catalytic current density varies from less than 1 mA cm−2 to more than 1000 mA cm−2 (Fig. 7 ). The substantial impact of the catalyst on the overall performance is evident. Like other deeply reduced Oxys, most electrocatalysts that generated ethanol at appreciable reaction rates are Cu single-metal and Cu-based multi-metal catalysts [20,21,75–84]. The choice of Cu stems from its ability to facilitate CO dimerization, a pivotal step in synthesizing ethanol [85,86]. Nonetheless, it is often impeded by the formation of by-products, particularly ethylene, which competes with ethanol production [15]. The FE of ethanol can be improved by modulating the composition and structure of the catalyst. This can be achieved by strategies such as doping with heteroatoms [75,78], creating heterojunctions [76,79–82], developing amorphous catalyst structures [21,87], adjusting the distribution and density of metal atoms [20], and introducing anionic and cationic defects [83,84]. Next, we will provide a detailed introduction to several representative catalysts for the production of ethanol. To date, Xu et al. hold the record for the highest FE (91%) for ethanol using a Cu-based catalyst Cu/C-0.4 [77]. This was achieved by an intricate process involving the atomic dispersion of copper on a carbon support by a molten lithium dispersion strategy. However, the maximum FE was only realized with an ethanol partial current density of less than 1.2 mA cm−2 (Fig. 8 a–c). Under these conditions, the atomically dispersed Cu atoms tend to form Cu n clusters (n = 3 and 4), probably because of the significantly higher surface energy of Cu than many other transition metals such as Fe, Co, Ni, and Mn [88]. Consequently, developing highly exposed atomic dispersed Cu-N x sites and reducing the distance between Cu-N x sites by forming a high density of active sites could be a promising yet challenging approach to achieve C–C coupling in ECR. Xia at al. synthesized ultra-high density Cu SAs on N-doped thin-walled carbon nanotubes that achieved a metal loading as high as 13.35 wt% (TWN-Cu13.35-600-SACs) with a FE of 81.9% for ethanol production [20]. Furthermore, the partial current density reached 35.6 mA cm−2, with stability exceeding 25 h (Fig. 8d–f). The design of efficient non-copper single-metal catalysts for ethanol production that exhibit superior performance remains a significant challenge [70,89–91]. Recently, Ding et al. reported an electrocatalyst composed of SnS2 nanosheets and atomically dispersed Sn atoms [92]. These Sn atoms were coordinated to an O-rich 3D carbon carrier by binding with three O atoms (Sn1-O3G). The SnS2/Sn1-O3G catalysts had a FE of 82.5% for ethanol production at −0.9 V, accompanied by a geometric current density of 17.8 mA cm−2. Furthermore, the catalyst showed commendable stability, retaining 97% of its initial activity after 100 h of operation (Fig. 8g–j). At present, the performance of single-metal catalysts for ECR to produce ethanol has made significant progress. However, achieving further breakthroughs is highly challenging and would greatly increase trial-and-error costs. Therefore, utilizing theoretical calculations and introducing multimetallic catalysts to aid in catalyst screening and prediction will be essential. Recent advances in high-throughput computation have simplified the screening process for potential electrocatalytic materials. The use of activity descriptors to describe the activity of various metals and their alloys is helpful for the rational design of catalysts [48,93]. Bagger et al. found that the adsorption energies of specific reaction intermediates, namely ΔE H*, ΔE CO*, ΔE COOH*, and ΔE CH3O*, could explain the product selectivity of ECR on most monometallic surfaces [94]. Vasileff et al. used the oxygen and hydrogen affinities of secondary metals to predict product selectivity for Cu-based catalysts [3]. The combination of Zn [95,96], Ag [97–100], and Au [49,101] with Cu can induce electronic and geometric effects, thereby reducing the activation energy for CO release and increasing ethanol production. For instance, in the CO2 reduction process of a Cu4Zn bimetallic catalyst, the first step is the reduction of CO2 to *CO by Cu or Zn active sites. Since *CO is weakly adsorbed at Zn sites, it can diffuse and spill over to Cu sites. *CO is further reduced to *CHO or *CH x at Cu sites (x = 1–3). *CO can also be inserted between Cu sites and *CH2 intermediates to form *COCH2, which is further reduced to produce C2H5OH [95]. In addition, the introduction of metals with weak *H adsorption capacity such as Fe [102], Sn [103], Bi [104], and V [105] to inhibit HER has also been proposed as a strategy to promote ECR for ethanol production. It is worth mentioning that both Zhang et al. [22] and Zhang et al. [106] reported increasing ethanol production by adding Lewis acid metal Al. The former used CuAl2O4/CuO derived from layered precursors to adjust the hydrogen coverage on the catalyst surface. At a current density of 200 mA cm−2, the catalyst had a FE of 70% for multicarbon products and 41% for ethanol in a flow cell (Fig. 9 a–c). The latter employed Al to adjust the oxophilicity of the Cu-based catalyst that had a performance in producing C2+ products with a FE of 84.5%, including C2+ alcohols with a FE of 55.2% and a partial current density of 354.2 mA cm−2 (Fig. 9d, e). Bimetallic based electrodes demonstrated a superior performance in producing alcohols and oxygenated compounds than single copper counterparts. However, the partial current density of C2H5OH (|j C2H5OH|) remains below 500 mA cm−2 and the FE is low at high electrolytic rates (|j total| > 600 mA cm−2). Inspired by previous studies, the introduction of halide anions [78] and alkali metal cations with large ionic radius [107,108] into copper-based catalysts could improve the yield of C2+. Peng et al. designed a copper catalyst (K-F-Cu-CO2) with surface F− and K+ co-modification, which was reconstructed from KCuF3 perovskite [109]. At a total current density of 800 mA cm−2, the |j C2H5OH| reached 423 mA cm−2, corresponding to a 53% FEC2H5OH (Fig. 9f, g). However, when the total electrolytic current density was further increased (e.g. > 1.2 A cm−2), the FEC2H5OH decreased significantly. To solve this problem, they recently selected the orthorhombic Cs3Cu2Cl5 perovskite as a precursor to fabricate a Cl− and Cs+ co-modified Cu catalyst (Cu-Cl-Cs) with a primary (200) face [110]. A Cu nanocube catalyst with a high (200)/(111) ratio (>30) was achieved after in-situ electrochemical reconfiguration at high current density. The Cu-Cl-Cs catalyst had a peak FEC2H5OH of 45.4% ± 2.3% at −1.34 V, with a total current of 4 A cm−2 and a high |j C2H5OH| of 1816 ± 92 mA cm−2 (Fig. 9h, i), which was significantly surpassing those in previous reports. For non-metallic catalysts, B- and/or N-doped C-based materials could achieve high ethanol selectivity, even surpassing 90% [60,61,111–113]. But the high selectivity was associated with partial current densities below 1 mA cm−2. At high total current densities, the selectivity and production rates of ethanol were much lower than those of other co-products, thus limiting the large-scale application of this technology. Further research is needed to understand the mechanism of ECR to ethanol over non-metallic catalysts in order to improve their performance. 2.4 Electrocatalysts for production of C3 oxygenates from CO2 Despite the high energy density and commercial value of C3 products, there are few studies on C3 Oxys such as n-propanol, isopropanol and acetone (Table S4, containing the full name and abbreviation of the catalyst in this section) [114]. The design of catalysts for C3 Oxys production is one of the most significant challenges in this field [23,24,115]. Since there are few reports on direct conversion of CO2 to C3 Oxys, we also include literature on electrocatalytic CO reduction to C3 Oxys for comparison. Most of the reported catalysts for selective production of C3 Oxys has a selectivity of less than 40% and a current density of less than 20 mA cm−2 (Fig. 10 ). But the selectivity of Fe-doped carbon nanotubes for C3 Oxys is outstanding, achieving over 90% selectivity at a current density of ∼20 mA cm−2. In addition, Cu94Ag6 solid solution materials also exhibit over 50% selectivity for C3 Oxys and higher catalytic current densities under pressurized conditions. It is important to note that the production of C3 Oxys requires significantly more electrons than C1 or C2 products, i.e., a lower concentration of C3 products under the same amount of electrolysis. Therefore, quantitative analysis of C3 products under small current electrolysis conditions needs to be performed with caution. Since copper catalyst was first reported for the electroreduction of CO2 to n-propyl alcohol in 1988 [116], several strategies have been implemented to improve the copper and Cu-based catalysts. These include structure reconstruction [117], two-step activation [118], creation of core-shell structures [119], and introduction of disulfide vacancies [120]. For example, Zhuang et al. found that modifying the Cu2S core with Cu surface vacancies resulted in a FE of 8%±0.7% for n-propanol production [119]. The nanoconfinement of C2 intermediates promotes C3 formation and thereby promotes C2-C1 coupling inside a reactive nanocavity. The same copper sulfide catalyst, Peng et al. reported a disulphide vacancy (DSV) structure through a lithium electrochemical method [120]. The presence of sulphur vacancies can reduce the oxidation of copper between 0 and +2, thus promoting C–C coupling. In an H-cell with a 0.1 M KHCO3 electrolyte, the CuS x catalyst had a FE of 15.4%±1% for n-propanol production at −1.05 V. In a flow cell with a 1 M KOH electrolyte, a partial current density of 9.9 mA cm−2 was achieved for n-propanol production at −0.85 V (Fig. 11 a–c). The above researches demonstrate that the stabilization of *C2 intermediates and subsequent coupling of C1-C2 intermediates facilitate the production of C3+ Oxys. Oxide-derived copper (OD-Cu) is also acknowledged as effective and practical electrocatalyst of ECR for multi-carbon production. A comprehensive investigation into the structure and properties of CuO and Cu2O in ECR was conducted by Long et al [121]. Due to its ability to remove oxygen from the original crystal, OD-Cu inherently possessed a rougher surface and more undercoordinated Cu sites than its Cu2OD-Cu counterpart. Those resulted in a FE up to 17.9% for n-propanol production at −0.94 V (Fig. 11d–f). Bicenter metal complexes with two adjacent metal centers may have the potential to initiate CC coupling and stabilize oxygen-containing intermediates through ligation effects. Yang et al. selected three bicentric copper complex models with extended porphyrin fluoride structure but different spatial and coordination geometries to explore the relationship between structure, property, and performance in ECR (Fig. 11g–j) [122]. Their study demonstrated that the combination of copper clusters and partially reduced oxygenated hexaphyrin ligands was efficient in the conversion of CO2 to n-propanol with a FE of 18.3%. These modifications have resulted in improvements in the FE and partial current density of n-propanol. However, due to the involvement of multiple steps in CC coupling, as well as the complexities of electron transfer and protonation, the ECR performance for propanol still lags behind that of methanol and ethanol production in terms of both efficiency and reaction rate. So far, the catalysts used in ECR to produce n-propyl alcohol are all copper-containing catalysts. Unexpectedly, Centi et al. found Fe-enriched CNTs promoted ECR to produce isopropanol in a solvent-free electrocatalytic cell at 60 °C [123–125]. The strategy was further explored by Rayer et al. They pyrolyzed two commercial copper-decorated MOFs (HKUST-1 and PCN-62) to create inks to coat metallic nickel and copper supports [126]. They found that the MOF-derived coating showed a high current density and an isopropanol selectivity over 72% (Fig. 12 a, b). Controlling local CO2 concentration ([CO2]) is known to promote CC coupling in ECR [119]. Qi et al. controlled the CO2 concentration above the saturation limit and developed a co-electrodeposition method to suppress galvanic exchange to obtain a CuAg alloy catalyst [114]. Under supersaturated conditions, the alloy achieved high performance in the production of isopropanol with a FE of 56.7% and a partial current density of 59.3 mA cm−2 (Fig. 12c–e). Through unconventional reaction conditions, such as using CO as the feed gas, increasing the gas partial pressure, or employing solventless cells, the researchers achieved a breakthrough in the production of isopropyl alcohol by ECR. This provides a good reference for the subsequent research. Highly selective production of acetone chemicals is less reported. Among them, the FEs of ZnO/Cu [127] and silver-doped copper [115] electrocatalysts for acetone preparation are 30% and 33% respectively. Given the potential of single-atom materials as active and selective electrocatalysts for CO2 reduction, Zhao et al. developed a catalyst composed of single-atom copper encapsulated in nitrogen-doped porous carbon (Cu-SA/NPC). This catalyst was specifically designed for the reduction of CO2 into multi-carbon products [23]. The primary product identified was acetone with a FE of 36.7% and a yield of 336.1 μg h−1 (Fig. 12f, g). Payra et al. developed a method to synthesize carbon-supported Cu1− x Zn x nanoalloy (Cu1− x Zn x /C) via the pyrolysis of MOFs [24]. The synthesized Cu0.85Zn0.15/C produced acetone with a FE of 38.1% (Fig. 12h, i). In summary, copper-containing catalysts are the only effective catalysts for the electrochemical reduction of CO2 to C3 Oxys under ambient temperature and pressure, but their FE remains low. This phenomenon can be attributed to the inherent difficulty of C2-C1 coupling on the surface of commonly used electrocatalysts, as well as the complex reaction mechanisms involved. To improve the yield of C3 Oxys, it is essential to clarify the true reaction pathways and actively optimize both the catalysts and the reaction systems in order to address this challenge. 3 Reaction mechanism of ECR for Oxys production Experimental methods and theoretical computational models play a crucial role in elucidating the factors that influence the diversity of products generated by ECR. It was found that the product variation depended on several parameters, including pH, applied potential, and presence of counter-ions [128–132]. It is widely accepted that CO2 is initially reduced to CO on various metal surfaces [14,133]. At low pH levels, CO can be further reduced to *COH or *CHO, and subsequently to *CH2OH, resulting in methane or methanol [129,134]. When the pH exceeds 7, CC coupling occurs to form *CO-CO dimers and *OC-COH [85]. The CC coupling process is endothermic, which is usually a rate-determining step (RDS) [86]. These insights are critical to the design of electrodes and the optimization of reaction system parameters, thereby directing the reaction paths towards the selective synthesis of desired products [135]. In this section, we discuss the progress made in describing the paths and mechanisms of Oxys formation to improve our understanding of these complex processes. 3.1 Mechanism of methanol production The reduction of CO2 to methanol requires six protons and electrons. The corresponding half-reaction equation and equilibrium potential are given by Eq. (1) [136]. (1) CO2 + 6H+ + 6e− → CH3OH(aq) + H2O E 0 = 0.034 V vs. RHE The mechanisms of ECR for methanol production are categorized into three primary paths, as depicted in Fig. 13 . Path 1 through *CO as an intermediate is recognized as the most common reaction mechanism. Low et al. proposed that CO2 was first adsorbed, then reduced to *COOH, *CO and *CHO, and finally methanol was produced through a series of hydrogenation processes [137]. The low binding energy between *CO and catalysts caused its release from the catalyst surface, which was not conducive to its further reduction to methanol. Using thermodynamic analysis, Peterson et al. proposed that the RDS of CH3OH formation was the protonation of *CO to *CHO or *COH [14]. These intermediates could subsequently undergo proton-electron transfer steps, yielding *OCH3 species. The hydrogenation of *OCH3 played a pivotal role in determining selectivity between CH4 and CH3OH. The results showed that Cu(211) was thermodynamically more favorable to the selective conversion of CO2 to CH4 than CH3OH. Nie et al. found that *CHO was a key intermediate in CH3OH production, while *COH played a key role in CH4 formation [138]. *COH could undergo a multi-step reduction process to form *C, *CH, *CH2, *CH3, and ultimately CH4. The activation barrier of *CO to *CHO was higher than that of *COH, which may explain the higher selectivity of CH4 than CH3OH observed in the experiment. Kuhl et al. suggested that methanol and methane shared partial reaction intermediates [139]. In methanol synthesis, only one C–O bond needed to be broken in CO2 by the catalyst, whereas for methane, two C–O bonds must be cleaved. If the catalyst broke two C–O bonds in the early stages of ECR, only CH4 could be formed as a C1 product. In another reaction mechanism (Path 2), Zhai et al. conducted DFT calculations on a silver catalyst modified by titanium dioxide to study the conversion of CO2 to CH3OH [140]. According to their research, CH3OH was produced through *OCHO intermediate, which were subsequently hydrogenated to *OCH2OH. Further hydrogenation may lead to the cleavage of the C–O bond to form CH3OH. Thermodynamically, the formation of CH3OH by *OCH2OH was more advantageous than the formation of CH4. Additionally, it was suggested that after *OCH3 is formed, the metals with moderate oxygen affinity had a preference for CH3OH than CH4. Coincidentally, Zhao et al. reported a CO2-methanol electrocatalysts, consisting of single-atom copper and nanoparticle Cu(100) anchored on MXene [141]. DFT calculations revealed that both electrocatalysts exhibited a preference for converting *CO2 into adsorbed *OCHO intermediates rather than *COOH intermediates. The preference arose from the thermodynamic advantage of forming the former, which reduced the possibility of formic acid production. In a recent study by Zhang et al., another methanol production mechanism was proposed (Path 3), highlighting the generation of CH3OH through a formyl intermediate [44]. They developed a catalyst based on molybdenum (Mo) metal carbide and N-carbon nanotube (CNT), which selectively generated CH3OH by ECR. The thermodynamic results showed that the modified hydroxyl Mo2C surface tended to adsorb *OCHO* intermediates rather than *COOH intermediates. CO2 was first converted to *OCHO* and then reduced to *OCH2*OH, *OCH2, and CH3OH. The RDS of *OCH2 hydrogenation to *OHCH2 had a lower energy barrier than hydrogenation to CH4, making CH3OH more selective than CH4. 3.2 Mechanism of acetic acid/acetate production The conversion of CO2 to acetic acid requires the transfer of eight protons and electrons. The corresponding half-reaction equation and equilibrium potential are given by Eq. (2). (2) 2CO2 + 8H+ + 8e− → CH3COOH(aq) + 2H2O E 0 = 0.11 V vs. RHE In order to elucidate the reaction paths and mechanisms of acetic acid preparation by ECR, researchers have employed various characterization techniques. There is a consensus that *COOH serves as a key intermediate during ECR process [142,143]. Nonetheless, the formation mechanism of acetic acid remains controversial [64]. Acetic acid/acetate can be produced in a variety of ways, as illustrated in Fig. 14 . There are theoretical computations and in-situ infrared spectroscopy (IR) suggesting that reduced *CH3 combines with CO2 molecules near the catalytic surface to form *OOCCH3 (Path 1). This reaction is advantageous because the absorbed *CH3 tends to participate in the nucleophilic attack of the radical anion *CO2 − [143]. Eventually, a protonation step occurs on the catalyst surface, resulting in the desorption of acetic acid [26,65]. The dimerization of *CO to *COCOH is a key step in the synthesis of C2+ products. The presence of highly active dual copper site, together with proximal protons, facilitates the C–C coupling process by reducing the Gibbs free energy barrier during *CO hydrogenation [25,66,142]. Other reaction paths have been elucidated using in-situ infrared spectroscopy, DFT calculations, and experimental techniques. These studies revealed that CO2 could be reduced to *CO and then dimerized on metal catalysts to form a ketene intermediate *CH2=C=O, which was part of Path 2 [144]. Moreover, Birdja et al. employed a catalytically inactive electrode boron-doped diamond (BDD) for ECR to clarify the disproportionation paths of formaldehyde, acetaldehyde, and propionaldehyde [145]. Their research revealed that the local alkaline environment near the electrode surface promoted the disproportionation of aldehydes into carboxylic acids and alcohols. During CO reduction at high pH, Li et al. noted an increase in acetate formation and a marked reduction in ethanol concentration on oxide-derived copper. These observations implied that the two C2 species shared an aldehyde intermediate (Path 3) [146]. CO2 was first adsorbed to the electrode surface and then reduced to *CO2 −. Liu et al. suggested that *CO2 − radical combined with another CO2 molecule to form *OOC-COO−. Oxalate intermediates were protonated and further reduced to acetic acid [62]. The infrared spectrum (1307 cm−1) of *OOC-COO− was analyzed. In the subsequent electrolysis process, the initial peak strength gradually increased and stabilized, indicating that *OOC-COO− served as an ECR intermediate. This supported the reaction path of oxalate intermediates (Path 4) [147]. In the case of insufficient number of H radicals around the nascent *COOH intermediate, the adjacent *COOH radical participated in the C–C bond and formed the oxalate. Further electroreduction of oxalate to acetic acid strongly verified this mechanism [69]. 3.3 Mechanism of ethanol production The conversion of CO2 to ethanol requires 12 protons and electrons [136]. The corresponding half reaction equation and equilibrium potential are shown in Eq. (3). (3) 2CO2 + 12H+ + 12e− → C2H5OH(aq) + 3H2O E 0 = 0.085 V vs. RHE Investigations on ethanol production by ECR have shown that there are multiple paths for C–C coupling, protonation, and electron transfer processes, as shown in Fig. 15 [138,148–150]. For the widely used Cu-based catalysts, Calle-Vallejo et al. studied the reaction mechanism of CO on Cu(100) surface [86]. Their research showed that the RDS was the coupling of two CO molecules. Electron transfer promoted the formation of *C2O2. *CO-COH was dehydrated to *CCO and hydrogenated to the *CH2CHO species (Path 1). Subsequently, the reaction may diverge. One possibility was that the remaining C–O bond broke and formed ethylene, leaving an adsorbed oxygen atom. Alternatively, the α carbon was hydrogenated to *CH3CHO and further converted to ethanol [90,151]. Thermodynamically, the formation of ethylene was about 0.2 eV more feasible than that of ethanol. Xiao et al. assumed that there were multiple competitive reaction paths in ethanol conversion, which shared certain key reaction intermediates identified as *CH = COH (Path 2) [134]. To determine the origin of oxygen atoms in oxygenated products, Lum et al. designed an experiment to reduce C16O in a H2 18O solvent [152]. Their findings showed that 66% of oxygen atoms on the surfaces of Cu(100), Cu(111), and Cu(751) were 18O, originating from the solvent. Therefore, they proposed a mechanism characterized by disproportionation of *CH = COH intermediates. The first possibility was the direct protonic reduction of *CH = COH to *CH-CH16OH intermediates, resulting in C2H5 16OH. The second possibility was the dehydration of *CH = COH to form *CH = C intermediate, and then the addition of H2 18O molecule to form *CH-CH18OH intermediate, and finally C2H5 18OH [153]. This study provided an explanation for the origin of the oxygen atoms in ethanol. In addition, Liu et al. analyzed the ECR effect of non-metallic materials on ethanol production through experiments and DFT, and proposed the free energy path of ethanol on the (111) plane of boron-nitrogen doped (BND) materials (Path 3) [61]. The authors suggested that two adjacent *CO could easily form *OC-CO by an exothermic reaction with free energy change of −3.32 eV. Moreover, the free energies of both the basic reaction and the entire ethanol production process were negative, indicating that the reduction of CO2 to ethanol on BND was thermodynamically favorable. Boron atoms promoted CO2 capture and *COOH → *CO, *COCHOH → *COCH2OH → *CHOCH2OH → *CH2OCH2OH by bonding with O atoms. Nitrogen atoms facilitated *H transfer in hydrogenation reactions. 3.4 Mechanism of C3 Oxys production The conversion of carbon dioxide to acetone requires 16 protons and electrons, and the conversion of propanol requires 18 protons and electrons. The corresponding half-reaction equations and equilibrium potentials are depicted in Eqs. (4) and (5) [136]. (4) 3CO2 + 16H+ + 16e− → CH3COCH3(aq) + 5H2O E 0 = 0.09 V vs. RHE (5) 3CO2 + 18H+ + 18e− → C3H7OH/CH3CHOHCH3(aq) + 5H2O E 0 = 0.10 V vs. RHE The synthesis of C3 Oxys by ECR is much more complex than the production of C1 or C2 products. Exploring the formation mechanism of C3 products requires a keen attention to the intermediates that arise during the reaction. Elucidating the role of these intermediates in the synthesis of C3 compounds calls for advanced analytical methods and computational models. In order to investigate the synthesis mechanism of acetone, graphite-supported single-atom copper coordinated with four pyridinic nitrogen atoms was selected as a model catalyst [23]. The thermodynamically most favorable path of ECR for CH3COCH3 was determined. The structure of all states generated on the Cu-pyrrole-N4 site was optimized and a path was proposed in the sequence (Fig. 16 , Path acetone): CO2 → COOH* → CO* → COCO* → COCOH* → COC* → COCH* → COCH2* → COCH3* → COCOCH3* → COHCOCH3* → CCOCH3* → CHCOCH3* → CH2COCH3* → CH3COCH3. In a parallel study, Da Silva et al. suggested that the formation of hydroxyacetone (COHCOCH3*) in copper catalysts could be attributed to further reduction of glyoxal (COCO*) or glycolaldehyde (COCOH*), subsequently coupled with CO [135]. The formation of n-propanol is similar to the synthesis of C2 alcohols, in which key *CO intermediates are coupled, setting the stage for subsequent reduction and protonation steps to eventually form an alcohol [154–156]. Previous theories suggested that adsorbed C2 intermediates could interact with adjacent C1 intermediates through intermolecular CC coupling. The interaction formd propanal (CH3CH2CHO), which was further reduced to C3H7OH (Fig. 16, Path n-propanol) [133,136]. Long et al. selected a representative CuOD-Cu catalyst with seven-coordination undercoordination Cu sites (denoted as Cu7c) to study the mechanism of n-propanol through DFT calculation [121]. The results showed that *HOCCOH and *CCH2 had negative CO coupling energy. *HOCCOH was thermodynamically more favorable for coupling with CO, which was consistent with the absence of *CCH2 in the Raman spectrum. Therefore, CC coupling was likely to occur between *HOCCOH and *CO intermediates on CuOD-Cu to produce C2+ products, including n-propanol. Moreover, Xu et al. used alkyl iodides to intercept the C1 and C2 intermediates during the CORR reaction. They found that n-propanol was mainly formed by the coupling of methyl carbonyl (adsorption of acetaldehyde) and *CO, while acetone was mainly formed via the coupling of methyl carbonyl and *CH3. This observation was consistent with their previous research [157,158]. Pablo-García et al. explored the formation mechanism of C3 compounds using both experimental and theoretical approaches, and they reached similar conclusions [159]. Although n-propanol and isopropanol are allotropes, their synthesis mechanisms are quite different. Rayer et al. used a carbonized copper MOF electrode to reduce ethanol to isopropyl alcohol [126]. The observed low yield of ethanol could be attributed to its consumption at the electrode during the production of isopropanol. At lower current densities, a reduction *CO dimerization process generated enol *C2H3O. The high surface density of *CO on the catalyst facilitated the coupling of *C2H3O with adjacent *CO to form new C–C bonds and produce C3 enol species. Additional proton-electron transfer could further reduce this component to yield isopropanol. Qi et al. demonstrated that the increased concentrations of *CO and *OCH2CH3 intermediates promoted isopropanol formation through isotope labeling experiments and Fourier transform infrared spectroscopy [114]. DFT calculations were performed to elucidate the reaction mechanism of isopropanol formation on both pure copper and copper-silver catalysts. The thermodynamic path involved the formation of *OCH2CH3, *CO*OCH2CH3, *COH*OCH2CH3, *CHOH*OCH2CH3, *CHOHCHOHCH3 and *CH = COHCH3 intermediates, resulting in isopropanol (Fig. 16, Path isopropanol). In conclusion, we have attempted to provide a comprehensive and systematic review of various pathways for Oxys synthesis by ECR. However, current characterization techniques are limited in their ability to identify only a few intermediates, with many more relying on theoretical predictions based on DFT. DFT typically relies on simplified static periodic boundary conditions, a limitation that may introduce deviations from real-world reaction scenarios. Moving forward, it is essential to conduct in-depth investigations into the true reaction pathways. This will not only help us to understand the complex formation process of specific compounds, but also pave the way for the rational design of efficient catalysts and regulation of reaction systems. 4 Performance regulation of ECR for Oxys production The pursuit of highly active and selective Oxys production by ECR remains fraught with substantial obstacles. This is mainly because completely oxidized linear CO2 molecule is thermodynamically stable, making its conversion challenging. Moreover, the electrocatalytic reduction of CO2 to Oxys is a complex multi-electron process that involves intricate mechanisms such as proton/electron transfer, surface adsorption, and the formation of intermediates. These lead to slow reaction kinetics and low FE [5,58]. Crucially, the performance of electrocatalysts is significantly influenced by their geometric and electronic structure [160]. These aspects directly affect the microenvironment around substrates and the adsorption strength of intermediates, and play a pivotal role in the efficiency of the catalytic process [6,161]. In addition, adjusting the operating parameters and regulating the system configurations are essential to improve the activity and selectivity of the ECR. Given these challenges, there is an urgent need to explore effective catalytic materials and systems. Current advances overcome the slow kinetics and low selectivity to some extent. In the following, we discuss the effects of geometric and electronic structure modulation of electrocatalysts and regulation of reaction systems on the synthesis of Oxys by CER. 4.1 Geometric structure modulation of electrocatalysts 4.1.1 Active site and support structure The geometric structure of catalysts' active sites plays a crucial role in obtaining specific compounds with a high yield and selectivity. Yang et al. synthesized a Cu2− x Se (1/3) nanocatalyst using a straightforward solvothermal method [162]. Structural distortion was induced by changing the ratio of copper to selenium atoms in the catalyst. Cu1.63Se(1/3) contained unsaturated selenium atoms, and its Cu-Se coordination number was significantly smaller than that of CuSe and Cu2Se. *CHO was more easily adsorbed on the surface of Cu1.63Se(1/3), resulting in a methanol partial current density of 41.5 mA cm−2 and a FE of 77.6% at a 285 mV overpotential. Long et al. demonstrated that CuO-derived Cu (CuOD-Cu) possessed more undercoordinated Cu sites than Cu2O-derived counterpart (Cu2OD-Cu) [121]. This leaded to a rapid kinetics of ECR process and promoted the binding of *C2 intermediates. As a result, CuOD-Cu attained a FE of 17.9% for n-propanol production, while Cu2OD-Cu mainly produced formic acid (Fig. 17 a–c). Hence, adjusting the crystal structure can change the coordination number of metal atoms at active sites, directly affect the adsorption energy of intermediates, and ultimately determine the reaction path. The interaction of Cu0 and Cu+ asymmetric sites with two CO molecules could produce different electronic structures that promote the C1-C1 coupling process [163]. Additionally, introducing atoms with a larger atomic radius onto the Cu surface can also create asymmetric sites [164], which are key factors in altering the material's electronic properties and enhancing its catalytic performance. Wang et al. investigated various M−doped Cu systems (M = Ag, Au, Ru, Rh, and Pd) and determined that the surface OCCO and CO coupling potentials are indicators of C1-C2 coupling [115]. Their calculations revealed that Ag-doped Cu had the lowest activation energy for both C1-C1 and C1-C2 coupling. The Ag-doped Cu gas diffusion electrodes (GDE) achieved a FE of 33% for n-propanol production, a conversion rate of 4.5 mA cm−2, and an energy conversion efficiency (EEcathodic half-cell) of 21%. Asymmetric sites can facilitate the C1-C1 coupling process [165,166]. Due to the similarity in the coupling process, these asymmetric sites can also promote C1-C2 coupling, leading to the generation of C3 products. In the past decade, there has been significant research on monomeric center catalysts, such as single-atom catalysts (SACs) [167,168] and transition metal macrocyclic complexes [169]. Studies indicate that modifying the coordination environment around the metal atoms in these catalysts can affect their catalytic performance [170], including the activity and selectivity in ECR [20,26,141,171]. For example, Wu et al. found that cobalt phthalocyanine molecules anchored on carbon nanotubes (CoPc/CNT) could reduce CO2 to methanol with a FE exceeding 40% and a partial current density surpassing 10 mA cm−2 at −0.94 V [172]. They noted that other cobalt macrocyclic complexes, such as cobalt chlorins and cobalt porphyrins, did not show selectivity for MeOH production even in the presence of carbon nanotubes. This highlighted the key role of the cobalt phthalocyanine molecular geometry in the six-electron reduction of CO2 to methanol. Despite these advancements, transition metal macrocyclic complexes and their monomeric centers are still limited to the formation of C1 products [18,19]. Metal complexes with two adjacent metal centers have the potential for CC coupling. These complexes can use the linking effect between the two metal centers to stabilize oxygen-containing intermediates, facilitating more complex reaction paths. Specifically, Yang et al. explored the potential of three bicentral copper complexes: Hex-2Cu-O, Hex-2Cu-2O, and Oct-2Cu [122]. Each was designed with extended and porphyrin fluorine structures. Among these, Hex-2Cu-2O complex had a stable structure but decreased catalytic activity. The intramolecular tension of Oct-2Cu complex not only affected its stability, but also increased its risk of decomposition under negative potential. Hex-2Cu-O complex stood out due to its apparent tension and coordination asymmetry. This particular structure resulted in a slightly lower stability, but significantly increased the number of active Cu centers. Moreover, loosely coordinated copper clusters formed in-situ played a key role in inhibiting competitive HER. This manipulation of the coordination environment broke the conventional linear scaling relationship between intermediates and promoted CC coupling. This breakthrough significantly increased the FE of alcohol to 32.5% and that of n-propanol to 18.3% (Fig. 17d–f). Similarly, Sakamoto et al. used Cu multinuclear metal complexes with a Br bridging ligand as a molecular catalyst that had a large number of π electrons and robust active sites [173]. Adsorption-desorption hysteresis due to CO2 adsorption and retention was observed in the metal complexes with close Cu active centers. At −2.2 V versus Ag/AgCl, the production efficiency of the C2+ products in total was 60% and that of C3H7OH was ∼10%. These findings highlight the potential of bicentric copper complexes and open the way for the formation of beyond-C1 products, potentially changing the landscape of ECR. The geometric structure of the support also influences the overall efficiency of the catalyst, as it plays a crucial role in the activation of CO2 molecules, as well as the transfer of electrolytes and reaction products. In order to solve the problem of low solubility of reactants in aqueous electrolytes, Li et al. added a microporous layer (MPL) made of carbon particles and fluoropolymers into their CoPc-NH2/CNT catalyst [18]. This addition improved the mass transport of CO and increased the FE for methanol production from 40% to 66%. The MPL may provide a more favorable environment for reactants to access active sites, thus improving the conversion efficiency. In addition, Su et al. investigated the effect of molecular curvature of single-walled carbon nanotubes (SWCNTs) on catalytic performance [19]. SWCNTs served as an excellent catalyst dispersant and conductive agent. When monodisperse cobalt phthalocyanine (CoPc) was supported on SWCNTs (CoPc/SWCNTs), the partial current density of the catalyst was greater than 90 mA cm−2, and the selectivity was greater than 60%. The performance was much better than that of multi-walled carbon nanotubes, with a selectivity of only 16.6% (Fig. 17h-j). Therefore, the active site and support structure have a significant influence on ECR activity and selectivity. Modifying the active site and support structure can provide additional anchoring sites for the active substance, enhance its adsorption capacity to the reactant molecules and intermediates, and also provide sufficient energy for the substrates involved in the catalytic reaction. 4.1.2 Active site density Typically, the highly dispersed active sites in SACs pose a major obstacle to CC coupling of C1 intermediates, thus limiting the production of larger C2+ molecules [174]. The Oxy produced by SACs is usually methanol. For example, Yang et al. reported that isolated Cu decorated through-hole carbon nanofibers (CuSAs/TCNFs) as a cathode in ECR produced methanol with a FE of 44% [171]. Zhao et al. immobilized single-atom Cu on MXene (SA-Cu-MXene) and promoted the electrocatalysis of CO2 to methanol by using Cu–O bonds [141]. The single-atom Cu catalyst attained a FE of 59.1% for CH3OH production. Interestingly, isolated copper sites are now being studied for their potential to synthesize acetate by coupling *CH3 with CO2 [65,175,176]. Crystalline porous frameworks, like PcCu-based covalent organic frameworks (COFs), with homogeneous and isolated CuN4 active sites, are emerging as candidates [26,177]. Isolated copper-phthalocyanine active sites, characterized by high electron density, played a pivotal role in promoting the crucial CC coupling between *CH3 and CO2, which facilitated the formation of acetate. Additionally, this catalyst configuration helped to avoid unwanted coupling reactions of *CO with *CO or *CHO, which could otherwise lead to the generation of ethylene and ethanol. High-density of active sites promotes the CC coupling of CO* species, which is applicable in the CO2-ethanol electrochemical reaction. The amorphous metal nanocrystalline catalyst has the characteristics of long-range disordered structure and low coordination number active site, and has strong CO adsorption capacity. Using machine learning technology, Chen et al. found that Cu(0) could be oxidized to amorphous CuxO by supercritical CO2 [21]. On this basis, amorphous shell copper nanoparticles (R-8-Cu-12) were synthesized by electroreduction method after supercritical CO2 treatment. R-8-Cu-12 was different from crystalline Cu catalysts, which had low coordination atoms. It was observed that amorphous Cu(0.5) had higher CO coverage and lower CO dimerization energy barrier than Cu(111). R-8-Cu-12 achieved a FE of 46.7% for ethanol production at −0.90 V and a partial current density of 149.44 mA cm−2 (Fig. 18 a–c). Wu et al. prepared ultrahigh-density Cu SACs on thin-walled N-doped carbon nanotubes (TWN) by means of silica-mediated hydrogen-bonded organic framework (HOF) [20]. They used different pyrolysis temperatures (500, 600, and 700 °C) to create Cu-N x SAs with different coordination numbers. The Cu/TWN-600 sample had a coordination number of 2.9 and a Cu mass content up to 13.35 wt% (Fig. 18d–g). DFT calculation results showed that the key intermediates in the ethanol path suppressed those of ethylene at high-density Cu-N3 active sites. Therefore, the Cu/TWN-600 had a high FE of 81.9% for ethanol production by ECR. An ideal electrode structure should have a large number of accessible active sites, which influence the surface coverage of CO intermediates and the residence time of reactants. This helps break the inherent linear scaling relationship, thereby improving the selectivity for C2+ oxygenated compounds [178,179]. Recent advances in CO2 electroreduction have improved the production of C2 products such as ethylene and ethanol. However, challenges remain in the synthesis of high-value C n products (n ≥ 3), especially acetone and propanol. These products exhibit low conversion efficiency, low EE, and limited stability [114]. Effective catalysts for C3 production must be active in both C1-C1 and C1-C2 coupling [3]. The distribution and coupling of intermediates are influenced by the spacing of active sites. Peng et al. proposed a disulphide vacancy (DSV) structure using a lithium electrochemical tuning approach [120]. It was discovered that a single sulfur vacancy (SSV) on CuS(100) could dimerize two CO into OCCO, yet it could not accommodate the strong electrostatic repulsion of three CO adsorbed at the center of a single sulfur vacancy at the same time. The distance between adjacent Cu atoms of the disulfide vacancy (DSV) was shorter (<3 Å), allowing CO-CO coupling. The negative charge was enriched near two adjacent coplanar vacancies, stabilizing the OCCO* dimer. In addition, it provided enough room for a third CO* to be further coupled to form a OC-COCO trimer, reducing the concentrated charge. The CuS x catalyst had a FE of 15.4%±1% in n-propanol production in an H-cell with 0.1 M KHCO3 at −1.05 V. In a flow cell containing 1 M KOH electrolyte, a partial current density of 9.9 mA cm−2 for n-propanol production was achieved at −0.85 V (Fig. 18h–k). In summary, the selectivity and activity of Oxys are intrinsically related to the coverage rate, adsorption energy and dimerization energy barrier of CO on the catalyst surface. The structure of the active site and carrier as well as the density of the active site plays a key role in determining the ECR path. 4.2 Electronic structure modulation of electrocatalysts In order to improve the selectivity of desired products while inhibiting the emergence of by-products, the binding energy of key intermediates must be optimized. Modulating electronic structure of catalysts, i.e. valence states, electronegativity, charge distribution, and polarizability, provides a direct avenue to influence adsorption dynamics of surface intermediates [3,180]. 4.2.1 Stabilizing oxygen-containing intermediates Optimizing the interaction between oxygen-containing intermediates and active sites is critical for Oxys. Current catalysts mainly use single doped cations or anions to change the binding strength of intermediates and inhibit competitive reactions such as HER, thereby improving the performance of the catalyst to generate methanol. Li et al. developed a double-doped catalyst that incorporated cations and anions into Cu2O/Cu host at the same time to investigate the relationship between heteroatoms and catalytic activity [13]. Doping anion (S < I < Se) adjusted the adsorption position of the *CHO intermediate and reduced energy barrier. Conversely, altering cation (Ag > Au > Cd > Zn) inhibited HER and potentially impacted the formation rate of methanol. This catalyst had a methanol FE of 67.4% and a partial current density of 122.7 mA cm−2 in an H-cell (Fig. 19 a–c). In addition, they designed Sn1-Ov Lewis acid-base pairs on CuO by atomically anchoring Sn sites on defective CuO catalysts [52]. Oxygen vacancy caused a change in the electronic structure with the appearance of a new defect energy level located near the peak of the valence band. The *CHO intermediate exhibited robust binding to Cu surface, and its formation process was exothermic. This process avoided CC coupling and improved the FE (88.6%) of methanol (Fig. 19d, e). Consequently, for CH3OH production, hydrogenation of *CO intermediates to *CHO is a crucial step, while *COH plays a pivotal role in the generation of CH4 [181]. Modulating the adsorption strength of *CHO intermediates and reducing ΔG values associated with *CHO formation are key to improving the selectivity of CH3OH. The bond energy of *–O and O–C in methoxy (*-O-CH3) determines whether the subsequent reaction proceeds via protonation or dihydroxylation to form CH3OH or CH4, respectively. Cation polarization and electronic delocalization, induced by strong coordination anions, result in soft metal sites. According to the hard-soft acid-base (HSAB) theory, the binding of soft metal sites to hard bases such as *O or *OCH3 is unfavorable. Kong et al. used HSAB theory to modify the electron delocalization state of Cu catalytic sites [16]. Cuprous cyanamide (Cu2NCN) crystals contain isolated Cu(I) ions whose electrons are strongly conjugated to NCN2−. The formation of CH3OH on Cu2NCN(100) had an energy advantage of 0.74 eV over the formation of CH4, thus favoring the formation of CH3OH. As a result, Cu2NCN had a good FE of 70% and a high partial current density of −92.3 mA cm−2 for CH3OH production (Fig. 19f, g). Recently, Liu et al. extended the HSAB theory to ethanol preparation. They modulated electron delocalization of Cu catalyst by a nitrene surface functionalization approach. As a result, the nitrene-functionalized Cu catalyst exhibited a much-enhanced ethanol FE of 45% with a peak partial current density of 406 mA cm−2, substantially exceeding that of unmodified Cu or amide-functionalized Cu [182]. Therefore, the selectivity of methanol is influenced by the surface oxygenphilicity of catalysts. The electrocatalytic reduction of CO2 to ethanol is primarily limited by the regulation of reaction intermediates and CC coupling. Peng et al. developed a Cu-Co bimetallic catalyst with CN vacancies using H2 cold plasma, enabling efficient conversion of CO2 to low-carbon alcohols [183]. Attenuated total internal reflection surface enhanced infrared absorption spectrum (ATR-SEIRAS) and DFT studies indicate that the spatial steric hindrance of VCN can enhance the generation of *COOH leading to CO, which in turn promotes CC coupling on uniformly dispersed Cu atoms. The Cu-Co PBA-VCN (Prussian blue analogue with CN vacancies) electrocatalyst achieved an ethanol FE of 44.6% at −0.9 V versus RHE, with good durability (100 h) and a low onset potential of −0.21 V. Similarly, Zhang et al. investigated a stable activation method for the Cu0/Cu+-on-Ag interface treated with N2 cold plasma, achieving an ethanol FE of 24.7% at −1.0 V versus RHE for Ag@Cu-CuN x [184]. Cu0/Cu+ could be tuned to form CuN x (Ag@Cu-CuN x ) on the Ag surface through nitrogen doping. The intermediates O*C*CO, *COOH, and *CO were detected. These two studies highlight the potential of low-temperature plasma treatment to enhance the formation of *CO intermediates, thereby accelerating both thermodynamic and kinetic CC coupling. It is widely recognized that both ethanol and ethylene share the same CH2CHO intermediate, which leads to intense competition in ECR paths [79,109]. The optimal catalyst for ethanol synthesis should stabilize the O–C bond in CH2CHO*. This critical step depends on the affinity of the catalyst for oxidation intermediates during the ECR process [99,103]. Li et al. synthesized a series of dendrite Cu-Sn bimetallic catalysts by substitution method to control the surface oxophilicity of catalysts [103]. The addition of Sn to Cu lattice significantly increased the generation of CO. The selectivity trend of C2H4 and C2H5OH was inversely proportional, which excluded the impact of tandem effect on CuSn x catalyst. This proved that oxophilicity was positively correlated with the yield of C2H5OH. The energy barrier of C2H5OH path decreased on CuSn x catalyst, consistent with the FE trend observed in experiment. Compared with copper, CuSn0.025 bimetallic catalyst had a superior C2H5OH selectivity of 25.93% and partial current density of 15.05 mA cm−2 at −1.4 V. The study highlighted that the increased oxophilicity of active sites helped to stabilize the key oxygen-containing intermediates and promote the formation of C2H5OH. Furthermore, once the *OC2H5 intermediates for ethanol production is formed, it is critical to inhibit the cleavage of the C–O bond therein to prevent the formation of ethylene. As an electron-deficient structure, Lewis acid site (such as Al3+ and Cr3+) can modulate the electronic structure of Cu atoms. This modulation alters surface nucleophilicity to regulate adsorbed C2+ oxygen species at active sites, thereby increasing the selectivity of ethanol production [185]. Zhang et al. screened various metal-doped Cu catalysts through DFT calculation [106]. They found that doping Al3+ not only stabilized the Cu+ component, but also modulated the nucleophilicity of the catalyst surface. The synthesized Al-doped Cu catalyst exhibited a high performance in producing C2+ products. Among them, the FE of C2+ alcohols was 55.2%, and the corresponding partial current density reached 354.2 mA cm−2 (Fig. 20 a–c). Therefore, Al is an ideal dopant for the preparation of C2+ alcohols by ECR. This strategy can be extended to other Lewis acid ions, such as Ga-doped Cu and Mg-doped Cu. Therefore, the above studies prove that the efficient conversion of CO2 to ethanol can be realized by modulating the surface oxophilicity and nucleophilicity of catalysts, and it is feasible to regulate by introducing co-metals. 4.2.2 Tailoring surface hydrogen coverage In addition to oxophilicity modulation mentioned above, the hydrogenation process is also an important research area. This is because the production of Oxys by ECR requires oxygen-containing intermediates to undergo a hydrogenation path, avoiding a dehydroxylation path that would otherwise lead to the formation of alkanes or alkenes. Therefore, the surface hydrogen coverage of catalysts is crucial in this process. Recent studies have proposed a range of H2O activation strategies. For example, Pd atoms or Cu clusters can provide appropriate hydrogen binding to adjacent Cu sites [175,186]. The effect of Ce(OH) x -doped interfaces on hydrogen adsorption of Cu surfaces has also being explored [187]. Additionally, F-modified Cu catalysts can also accelerate the dissociation of H2O [78]. However, these strategies mainly focused on either H2O dissociation or hydrogen adsorption. There is a significant gap in our understanding of the roles of H2O dissociation, *H coverage, and *H migration in ethanol production at an atomic level. Zhang et al. reported an Rh1Cu4 alloy catalyst, where isolated Rh sites were uniformly distributed in the Cu framework [50]. They discovered that Rh1Cu4 was more favorable to the adsorption of H than Cu. Theoretical calculations indicated that the addition of Rh reduced the charge density around Cu and strengthened the electron attraction, thus facilitating the protonation reaction from *CO to *CHO. The high *H coverage of the Rh1Cu4 catalyst facilitates hydrogenation to produce methanol, rather than dehydroxylation to produce CH4 or C2+. In fact, the Rh1Cu4 catalyst achieved a high partial current density of 111.7 ± 12.8 mA·cm−2 and a FE of 46.2% ± 5.3% for methanol production (Fig. 20d, e). This work provides a way to promote methanol production by tailoring hydrogen coverage. Furthermore, Zhang et al. reported a layered double hydroxides (LDH) precursor derived CuAl2O4/CuO catalyst mediated by active hydrogen (*H) intermediates for ethanol electroproduction [22]. A series of experiments revealed that the *H coverage of CuAl2O4/CuO was higher than that of CuO. In-situ generation of CuAl2O4 on CuAl2O4/CuO effectively stabilized the Cu+ sites, thereby promoting CC coupling. Simultaneously, Cu-Al bridge sites on CuAl2O4 facilitated H2O dissociation to form adsorbed *H and adjusted local *H coverage. In addition to *H coverage, the energy barrier of *H spillover to CuAl2O4 was also lower than that of CuO. The increase of *H coverage on CuAl2O4(004)/Cu2O(111) promoted the hydrogenation of carbon atoms, which was conducive to the preservation of OH groups, the formation of *HCCHOH and the generation of ethanol. This catalyst had a FE of 41% for ethanol production at a current density of 200 mA cm−2, and showed a durability for 150 h (Fig. 20f–h). Around the same time, Zhang et al. developed a Cu-Zn alloy/Cu-Zn aluminate composite using Cu-Zn-Al LDH as precursors [188]. They were decomposed into uniform Cu-Zn oxides/Cu-Zn aluminate pre-catalysts. Under electrochemical reduction, Cu-Zn oxides formed Cu-Zn alloys while the aluminate oxides remained unchanged. ATR-IRAS analysis revealed that the presence of aluminate at the interface significantly enhanced the activation of CO2 adsorption and the dissociation of H2O, strengthening the adsorption of CO intermediates and facilitating CC coupling to generate C2+ products. Therefore, Oxys selectivity is influenced by the adsorption energy of oxygen-containing intermediates and the surface hydrogen coverage of catalysts. 4.2.3 Generation of multi-carbon products To accelerate the production of C2+ Oxys, it is also crucial to reduce the energy barrier of CO2 activation and promote the coupling of intermediates [22,189,190]. Zhou et al. examined the electronic properties of boron-doped copper using PDOS [75]. They observed that the CO adsorption energy increased monotonically with the increase in copper oxidation state. By constructing a volcano plot between the CO-CO dimerization energy and the average CO adsorption energy, they determined the optimized CO adsorption energy to be 0.8–1.0 eV and the optimal oxidation state to be around δ 0.2+. Furthermore, the average oxidation state of copper was volcanically correlated with the FE of C2. The Cu0/Cu+ interface in partially oxidized Cu matrix is conducive to CO2 activation and CC coupling, which is beneficial to increase the yield of C2. Despite the potential of Cu+ species in catalysis, their instability under reducing conditions poses a challenge for widespread application. This limitation can be mitigated by the incorporation of secondary metals (Ag, Pd, Au) [99,100,191,192], metal oxides (BaO, CeO2, Al2O3, ZrO2, SiO2) [193–197], and heteroatoms (including sulfur, boron, and halogen) [75,78,80,84] or carbon [198] into Cu-based catalysts to preserve the Cu+ species. Feng et al. demonstrated that single-atom Gd-doped Cu2O could stabilize Cu+ and induce tensile strain in the catalyst [190]. A Gd-doped CuO x catalyst (Gd1/CuO x ) with moderate CO binding energy was synthesized, facilitating CO2 to CO conversion and suppressing HER. At the same time, the 2*CO-to-O*CCO step displayed a negative thermodynamic change, thereby improving the stability of the key intermediate OCCO. This catalyst achieved a FE of 81.4% for C2+ production at −0.8 V and a partial current density of 444.3 mA cm−2 (Fig. 21 a–c). This is due to the unique electronic structure of 4f electrons and unoccupied 5d orbitals in lanthanide metals (LMs) allowing them to effectively regulate the local electron density of neighboring atoms, thereby keeping them in a hypervalent chemical state [199]. To avoid the ethylene production paths, metal ions that have a strong affinity for oxygen atoms, such as Sn or Bi, can be used in place of copper ions. This strategy forms an asymmetric active site that prevents premature hydrogenation of oxygen atoms, and forms *CO–*OCH2 intermediates, which is conducive to the selective production of ethanol (Fig. 21d) [99,115,153]. Zhao et al. developed MOF (CuSn-HAB) featuring heterometallic Sn-Cu dual sites, consisting of a pair of SnN2O2 and CuN4 sites bridged by μ-N atoms [200]. During ECR, they noticed stretching vibration of #CO (# represents Cu adsorption site) and *OCH2 (* signifies Sn adsorption site). Moreover, CH bending vibration peaks of primary intermediates #CO–*OCH2 and CH3CH2O* were also detected. SnN2O2 site had a strong affinity for *OCH2. The asymmetric CC coupling of #CO and *OCH2 to form #CO–*OCH2 and the hydrogenation of CH2OH–*OCH2 to produce CH3CH2O* species were thermodynamically favorable. As a result, CuSn-HAB had a FE of 56% and a partial current density of 68 mA cm−2 for alcohols at −0.57 V (Fig. 21e, f). In summary, the selective synthesis of C2+ Oxys depends on promoting CC coupling and maintaining C–O bond. The electronic structure modulation of catalysts can significantly affect the binding energy between active sites and oxygen-containing intermediates, as well as *H coverage, which are key factors to improve the selectivity of ethanol. 4.3 Operational parameters adjustment and system configurations regulation Adjusting operation parameters, such as temperature [201,202], overpotential [172,203,204] and gas partial pressure [18,27,71], as well as regulating system configurations, including electrolytes [74,205–207] and electrolytic cells [17,37,41,42,208,209], have important effects on ECR activity and selectivity. 4.3.1 Operational parameters adjustment Reaction temperature is a key parameter of ECR. The Arrhenius equation reveals that the reaction rate of a wide range of chemical reactions increases with increasing temperature, including endothermic and exothermic processes. Therefore, the efficiency and yield of different products in ECR will change with the reaction temperature. Vos et al. conducted an investigation on the impact of reaction temperature from 18 to 70 °C on copper performance [202]. Their study revealed that as the reaction temperature increased, the selectivity of C1 products diminished. In contrast, the selectivity and activity of C2+ products peaked at approximately 48 °C. At elevated temperatures, such as 70 °C, HER dominated and CO2 was mainly reduced to CO. Cathode potential is another important parameter that affects the selectivity of ECR products. Mechanistically, CO, CH3OH, and CH4 share certain intermediates. To generate CO or CH3OH, the catalyst first needs to cleave one C–O bond in CO2. To produce CH4, the two C–O bonds must be cleaved [139]. Two-electron reduced CO can be achieved at low overpotentials. Six-electron reduced CH3OH needs higher overpotentials (i.e., more negative). Eight-electron reduced CH4 requires the breaking a second C–O bond at even higher overpotentials to effectively catalyze its formation. Nonetheless, H2 becomes the primary product at more negative potentials. This is mainly due to the fact that the mass transfer rate of H+ is faster than that of CO2 at low potentials [56].
