For instance, Zhang et al. reported a molecular catalyst by anchoring cobalt phthalocyanine (CoPc) molecules to carbon nanotubes. At −0.63 V, the CoPc/CNT hybrid catalyst had a high and stable current density of 10 mA cm−2 with a FE of 90% for CO production [204]. By reducing the potential, the same catalyst CoPc/CNT promoted the six-electron reduction of CO2 to methanol with a FE exceeding 40% and a partial current density surpassing 10 mA cm−2 at −0.94 V (Fig. 22 a–c) [172]. Combined with previous studies, it can be inferred that for the same catalyst, the variation in CO and methanol production with applied potentials is due to the difference in the reduction mechanism of these chemicals. Recently, researchers have shown increasing interest in exploring how the partial pressure of reactant gases affects the activity and selectivity of the desired products [18,27,71]. Li et al. found that the RDS of CO electroreduction for methanol was the step of *CO hydrogenation to *CHO [18]. When p CO increased from 0.01 atm to 1 atm, the yield of methanol was first-order dependent on p CO. This indicated that increasing p CO may be an effective strategy to improve methanol production without limiting absorption. At a CO pressure of 10 atm, the FE of methanol was 84%, and the partial current density was 23.5 mA cm−2 at the optimal potential of −0.98 V, which increased the selectivity of methanol by 2 times (Fig. 22d–f). The above results are consistent with Henry's law, which states that the amount of gas dissolved in a given volume of liquid is proportional to the partial pressure at gas-liquid equilibrium. Increasing the partial pressure of the reaction gas can improve the solubility of CO2/CO and accelerate the reaction kinetics. Studies showed that monodentate C2 intermediates are directly related to the production of acetate, whereas bidentate-bound intermediates tend to produce ethylene, ethanol, and n-propanol [210]. When Ag and Au were used as hosts for Cu, monodentate-binding *C=C=O was superior to bidentate-binding *C=COH, preferring acetate to other C2 products. To improve the selectivity of acetate, Jin et al. developed isolated Cu clusters in favor of monodentate intermediates [71]. They explored various metal compositions, including Ag, Au, Pd, Pt, and Ni, in dilute alloy surfaces (Cu/M-DA) because they were similar to Cu in volume crystal space group and CO binding energy. Using a high pressure (10 atm) of CO, they achieved a FE of 91% for CO-to-acetate and maintained 85% FE after 820 h of continuous operation (Fig. 23 a–d). This work highlighted the importance of increasing the coverage of *CO by promoting the formation of monodentate C2 intermediates and boosting the partial pressure of CO, thereby improving the acetate selectivity. Similarly, increasing the concentration of [CO2] can also elevate the concentration of CO intermediates on catalyst surfaces, facilitating the multi-site binding mechanism that is crucial for the formation of multi-carbon products [119]. Specific trends observed include transitions from ethylene to ethanol production [211], from hydrocarbons to formic acid [212], and from methane to ethylene [213] at high CO2 pressures. Moreover, low HCO3 − concentration leads to a shift from methane to ethylene production via CC coupling [213]. Li et al. developed a Cu(OH)2-derived Cu/CuOx catalyst that yielded an 87% FE of acetate in the presence of borate additives at 58 atm CO2(g) [27]. With the increase of [CO2(aq)] and the decrease of HCO3 − concentration, the adsorption of Cu–O bonds on Cu(I) exceeded the adsorption of Cu–C bonds on Cu(0). Primary reduction product was converted from hydrocarbons to alcohols and then to carboxylates, with product selectivity shifting from C1 to C2 (Fig. 23e, f). Efficient acetate generation was attributed to the formation of *OC·O* with a second one-carbon species at active Cu(I) sites in the absence of protons. To overcome the saturation limit of CO2, Qi et al. developed a co-electrodeposition technique to fabricate a CuAg alloy catalyst, effectively reducing galvanic replacement [114]. Once the CO2 concentration in the electrolyte attained a supersaturated state, it was anchored to the defect location. As the concentration of [CO2] increased, the ratio of CO (*CObridge) to *CO affixed atop metal atoms (*COatop) increased linearly. There was a volcano-shaped correlation between *CObridge/*COatop ratio, isopropanol FE, and potential. These findings indicated that a high *CObridge/COatop ratio promoted CC coupling activation and favored isopropanol formation. Furthermore, Ag atoms dispersed in Cu accelerated the generation rate of *CO and *OCH2CH3 intermediates near the Ag sites in alloys and strengthened the C–O bond at the 2-position of C3 chain. However, this process destroyed the stability of CuAg*–O bond, resulting in the preferential formation of isopropanol. Under supersaturated conditions, this alloy catalyst had a FE of 56.7% and a specific current density of 59.3 mA cm−2 for isopropanol synthesis (Fig. 23g–i). In addition to external pressurization, Cai et al. reported the design of self-pressurizing nanoscale capsule catalysts for ECR [214]. A high-pressure (8 ± 3 bar) CO intermediate environment was created around copper catalysts by a permselective enclosure. Due to the kinetic and energetic advantages of COCO2*, the acetate FE (38.5% ± 2.2%) was 8 times higher than that achieved without enclosure and the acetate partial current density was 328 ± 19 mA cm−2. It is worth noting that moderate local CO2 concentrations favor CO-CO coupling and facilitate the synthesis of C2+ compounds. But excess CO2 interferes with *CO intermediates at active sites, hindering CO-CO coupling in favor of CH3-CO2 coupling, which leads to the generation of acetic acid [209]. 4.3.2 System configurations regulation The ECR process occurs at three-phase interface and involves gases, electrodes, and electrolytes. Electrolytes play a key role in determining the reaction outcome [215,216]. Research on ionic liquids (ILs) has increased significantly in recent years, attributed to their exceptional solubility for CO2, broad potential window, remarkable thermal stability, and high ionic conductivity (Fig. 24 a) [205–207]. Han et al. conducted an investigation on the impact of ILs, specifically [Bmim][BF4]/MeCN as electrolyte [56,162]. Their findings suggested that ILs presented a promising strategy for the efficient production of methanol by ECR. However, there are difficulties in separating liquid products using conventional electrolytes including ILs. Carbonates are produced and delivered at high current densities, resulting in seriously carbon and energy losses, which are often overlooked but hinder commercialization [217]. Zhu et al. developed new catalytic reactors, such as solid electrolyte reactors, which could directly produce high-purity and high-concentration liquid fuels without the need for downstream product separation processes [74]. They reported the continuous electrocatalytic conversion of CO2 into pure liquid fuel solutions in a cell using porous solid electrolytes. In this process, the electrochemically generated cations and anions combined to form a pure product solution without mixing with other ions (Fig. 24b) [33,218]. The alteration of electrolytes requires a corresponding upgrade of reactors. Currently, various electrochemical electrolytic cells have been employed for ECR, including H-cells [37,41,42,208], flow cells [17,203], membrane electrode assemblies (MEAs) [209], and MEA stacks [4,219]. In recent decades, three-electrode H-cells have been widely used due to their simplicity of operation, wide availability, and cost effectiveness (Fig. 24c) [8]. These cells have advanced the optimization of catalysts and elucidation of reaction mechanisms [37,41,42,208]. However, the low solubility of CO2 in aqueous electrolytes (∼33 mM at 25 °C) greatly inhibits mass transfer (diffusion coefficient D CO2 at 25 °C = 0.00194 mm2 s−1) [220,221]. This restricts the reaction rate, leading to a current density below 100 mA cm−2. To overcome the above challenges, flow cells with gas diffusion electrodes (GDEs) have been proposed (Fig. 24d) [222]. This configuration uses CO2 stream as the direct feedstock for the cathode, thereby reducing the limitation of CO2 mass transfer. A flow cell consists of three chambers and a polymer electrolyte membrane (PEM), which acts as a separator between the electrode chambers. Catalysts are located on GDEs as the cathode in ECR. Flow cells exhibit superior ECR performance than H-cells, attributed to the triple interface structure of the local gas-catalyst-electrolyte system [17,50]. Operating voltage is a crucial performance indicator as it determines energy efficiency (EE). Commercial devices need to operate at voltages below 3 V while maintaining current densities exceeding 200 mA cm−2 [203]. Despite its significance, operating voltages of an H-cell or flow cell are rarely reported. This is due to the presence of an electrolyte solution between cathode and anode with relatively high resistance, which limits the EE of these devices. MEA, known as a zero-gap electrolyzer, adopts a sandwich structure with a polymer electrolyte membrane between cathode and anode (Fig. 24e) [223]. Consequently, MEA-based cells can significantly reduce mass/electron transfer resistance, leading to high current density and EE [16,209]. Presently, large-area electrolyzers based on MEA and multi-reactor stacks are employed for scalable ECR, as illustrated in Fig. 24(f) [219]. Scalable electrolyzers are important in reducing costs associated with industrial applications and advancing the industrialization of ECR. 4.3.3 Innovative reaction systems In view of the challenges of low selectivity of C2+ products in non-alkaline electrolytes and the tendency to form carbonate in alkaline electrolytes [72], it is expected to solve these problems by adjusting the configuration of electrocatalytic systems to achieve “tandem catalysis” and decoupling the multi-step reaction process of ECR. This strategy can be divided into three types. (i) Tandem of different active sites: This involves introducing multiple active sites on a single catalyst and constructing interfaces or heteroatoms to modulate the intrinsic activity of catalysts [175,191,224,225]. These have been discussed in the previous sections Cu-based multi-metal, non-Cu multi-metal catalysts. (ii) Tandem of different catalysts (series catalysts with vertical stacked structures): These are formed by coating two different catalysts separately or by self-assembly [226]. For instance, SnS2 nanosheets have been found to electroreduce CO2 into formic acid, whereas Sn SACs can convert HCOOH to ethanol [227]. Ding et al. observed a fascinating phenomenon that a mechanical blend of SnS2 nanosheets and Sn SACs could yield ethanol with a FE value close to 15% [92]. They then reported a Sn-based tandem catalyst composed of SnS2 nanosheets and individual Sn atoms anchored on a 3D carbon support via localized SnO3 clusters (Sn1-O3G). Formate was produced by SnS2 nanosheets, while *OCO(OH) bicarbonate intermediates were produced by Sn1-O3G sites. The production of ethanol may be attributed to CC coupling between these two intermediates. The Sn1-O3G catalyst could yield intermediates containing Sn-C-C-O four-membered rings, which provided a platform for the formation of CC bonds to produce ethanol. The tandem catalyst achieved a FE of 82.5% and a partial current density of 17.8 mA cm−2 for ethanol production at −0.9 V (Fig. 25 a–f). (iii) Tandem of different reactors: In this scheme, the CO2-CO conversion is realized in the first reactor with a non-alkaline electrolyte and the CO-C2+ conversion occurs in the second reactor using an alkaline electrolyte. This tandem reaction system is mainly used in engineering research [19,228]. Synthesis of C3 Oxys by ECR requires multiple active sites responsible for reducing CO2 into CO intermediates. These intermediates are subsequently connected by C–C bonds [67,229]. Given the crucial role of CORR in enhancing the yield of C3 Oxys [115,119,146,230], Wu et al. used a system composed of two tandem electrolytic cells to convert CO2 to CO and CO to n-propanol, avoiding the storage and use of high-pressure CO [228]. First and second catalysts were 3D single-atom nickel (3D Ni-SAG) and multi-hollow Cu2O. This resulted in a FE of 15.9% and a half-cell EE of 19.3% for n-propanol production (Fig. 25g, h). Tandem of different reactors strategy can expand the choice of catalysts and facilitate the commercial production of CO2 derived C3 oxygen. Continuing to develop innovative reaction systems is crucial. Firstly, current ECR is generally matched with oxygen evolution reactions, yet the low-value O2 produced cannot compensate for the high energy consumption caused by water oxidation. The “cathode-anode synergy” strategy has been proposed to oxidize or couple methane at the anode to generate liquid oxides rather than O2 [231]. This not only reduces the overall voltage but also enables the entire system to produce high-value-added products, further enhancing economic benefits. Secondly, most of the current ECR studies focus on high-purity CO2, except for a few research groups that have reported using simulated flue gas as a gas source [232]. Essentially, this approach shifts the cost burden onto the CO2 capture process. The industrialization of ECR must move beyond this “comfort zone”. Therefore, it is necessary to develop a “integrated separation and conversion” strategy that directly utilizes low concentration CO2 flue gas, avoiding the regeneration, transport, and storage of capture media, and improving overall economic efficiency. Finally, although ECR can produce deeply reduced Oxys, they still belong to bulk chemicals with relatively low added value. The “electrochemical-biological hybrid synthesis” method aims to further convert low-purity oxygenated liquid products into high-value products, such as glucose and fatty acids [233]. This strategy contributes to enriching the downstream industrial ecosystem and systemic diversity of the ECR field, helping to foster low-carbon, next-generation productive capabilities. Therefore, adjusting operational parameters and optimizing system configurations can improve the reaction rate and Faradaic efficiency of ECR-produced Oxys. Combining these with innovative reaction systems will further facilitate breakthroughs in the energy efficiency and economic challenges currently faced by ECR. 5 Techno-economic analysis and environmental implications 5.1 Techno-economic analysis of ECR The cost of electricity and the efficiency of electrolyzers are the main economic barriers to the industrial development of ECR. Preliminary techno-economic analysis (TEA) suggests that electrochemical CO2 conversion to CO and formic acid is economically feasible [4]. For example, in a report by Jiao et al. [234], TEA of CO2 industrial electrolysis was conducted using both stack and single-chamber electrolyzers. When a three-chamber stack replaced the single-chamber MEA, the cost of CO2-to-CO electrolysis was calculated to be $0.37 kg−1, compared to $0.41 kg−1 for the single-chamber MEA. The results indicated that a plant using a single-chamber MEA would incur losses, while a plant using the three-chamber stack would generate profits. This analysis only considered the reduction in the cost of the electrolyzer itself and the maintenance costs associated with the stack, without accounting for the additional value-added costs of external equipment (if value-added costs are considered, the difference between the two would be even greater). However, the production of liquid products such as methanol, acetic acid, ethanol, and propanol—focusing on the present paper—still faces significant economic challenges. Fortunately, recent studies on renewable energy generation have shown a significant downward trend in the cost of photovoltaic (PV) power. In the near future, the price of PV electricity could drop to as low as $0.03 kWh−1. If the deep reduction of liquid products reaches reasonable electrochemical performance benchmarks (e.g., 300 mA cm−2 and a 0.5 V overpotential with 70% FE), ECR for the production of fuels and chemicals could become a profitable option, integrated into the growing renewable energy infrastructure [235]. Furthermore, we compare the TEA of ECR and traditional CO2 capture and conversion processes in terms of raw material costs, energy consumption, product separation and purity, sustainability and environmental costs and equipment investment and maintenance: Raw material costs: If CO2 is sourced from direct air capture (DAC), approximately 6.5 GJ of energy is required per ton of CO2, which itself represents a significant cost factor [236]. For industrial point-source capture, costs may be lower, but this depends on the concentration and purity of CO2 at the emission source. In ECR, the proton source comes from water, while in conventional CO2 capture and conversion, the proton source typically comes from hydrogen. When normalized to an equivalent amount of protons, the price of hydrogen is about 300 times that of water. Additionally, electrochemical methods can typically operate under milder reaction conditions, avoiding harsh conditions such as high temperature and pressure, which further reduces raw material consumption and equipment costs. Many traditional processes, such as thermal catalysis, often require high-temperature or high-pressure environments, necessitating higher durability of equipment and thus greater capital costs. Some processes also require high-purity hydrogen and other materials, which come with higher acquisition and storage costs [237]. Energy consumption: ECR generally relies on electricity, and optimizing electrodes and catalysts can lower energy consumption. However, the current efficiency of electrochemical processes is relatively low, resulting in higher electricity requirements per unit of product. Using renewable electricity can effectively reduce carbon emissions and costs. Moreover, developing catalysts with high Faradaic efficiency and low overpotential can significantly decrease overall energy consumption. In contrast, many traditional processes depend on fossil fuels, which can lead to fluctuating energy costs and substantial carbon emissions. Some processes can improve efficiency through heating and pressure, their carbon footprint and energy costs are comparatively high [238]. Product separation and purity: ECR typically produces mixed gases or liquids, leading to relatively high separation costs. For the resulting oxidized products (such as formic acid and ethanol), additional purification steps are necessary. Advanced membrane separation or integrated electrolysis technologies can reduce separation difficulties, but equipment and operational costs remain important considerations. In traditional chemical processes, product separation is relatively mature, with many techniques achieving efficient industrial-scale separation. For liquid products, methods such as distillation and extraction can provide efficient separation with better cost control [74]. Sustainability and environmental costs: Compared to traditional chemical processes, ECR has a smaller carbon footprint, particularly when powered by renewable energy sources, making it a more sustainable option. In the long term, policy incentives and the gradual maturation of carbon trading markets will highlight the green and low-carbon advantages of electrochemical reduction. Traditional processes that rely on fossil fuels contribute significantly to carbon emissions. Considering environmental management and carbon emission costs, the future economic viability of these processes may decline [239]. Equipment investment and maintenance: The equipment required for ECR, such as electrolyzers and electrodes, requires initial investment. However, the overall process operates under milder environmental conditions, leading to relatively low equipment wear. Moreover, the scalability potential of electrochemical reaction systems is significant, making them suitable for small and distributed applications. In contrast, traditional chemical processes often require high temperatures and pressures, resulting in higher equipment costs and maintenance expenses. Particularly under high-temperature and corrosive conditions, equipment lifespan is shorter, and safety requirements for production are heightened [240]. In summary, ECR holds future economic advantages, especially as electricity becomes renewable, catalyst efficiencies improve, and separation technologies advance, effectively lowering unit costs. In contrast, traditional CO2 capture and conversion processes face higher environmental and policy costs due to carbon emissions issues. Therefore, with technological advancements and optimizations in the energy structure, the economic feasibility of ECR is expected to strengthen over time. 5.2 Environmental implications of ECR In the process of ECR, understanding and assessing its environmental implications, sustainability, and carbon footprint are crucial. The following are some key influencing factors and assessment directions. Source of electricity and energy efficiency: The carbon footprint of electrochemical processes largely depends on the source of the electricity used. If renewable energy sources (such as solar and wind power) are utilized, greenhouse gas emissions during the process can be significantly reduced. However, if the electricity comes from fossil fuels, this process may produce more carbon emissions than the CO2 it reduces. Improving the EE of ECR (e.g., by enhancing electrode materials and reaction conditions) can lower the energy consumption per unit product, thereby increasing overall sustainability [241]. Choice of catalysts and their lifespan: Certain catalysts (e.g., precious metals) have significant environmental impacts during their production and extraction. Using inexpensive and abundantly available metals (such as Cu and Zn) is a more sustainable choice. Extending the lifespan of catalysts can reduce the environmental burden during long-term operations and decrease the frequency of catalyst manufacturing and replacement. Resource consumption and byproduct management: In electrochemical reactions, water is often consumed as a proton source, so the demand for and management of water resources also affect the sustainability of the system. Some byproducts of ECR (such as methane or formic acid) may require additional treatment to avoid potential environmental impacts [242]. Life cycle assessment (LCA): LCA is an effective tool for evaluating the environmental impact of ECR processes. It provides a comprehensive environmental analysis of the system from raw material extraction, production, use, to disposal, measuring carbon emissions over the entire life cycle [243]. Carbon footprint analysis can focus on the greenhouse gas emissions per unit product. By accurately assessing energy consumption and reaction efficiency, processes can be optimized, reducing overall carbon emissions. Integrating the ECR process with renewable energy systems, such as solar and wind power, and even combining its byproducts with other industrial processes to form a closed-loop system, holds the potential to achieve higher resource utilization and carbon reduction. By improving the process, utilizing sustainable materials, and enhancing system efficiency, the carbon footprint of ECR can be significantly reduced, which is crucial for achieving net-zero carbon emissions goals. 5.3 Roles of policies and incentives The promotion of ECR technology largely depends on policies and incentive measures. Carbon pricing mechanisms, such as carbon taxes and carbon trading markets, can increase the economic costs of CO2 emissions, encouraging companies to adopt low-carbon technologies [244,245]. At the same time, governments can set renewable energy targets to promote the integration of electrochemical reduction technologies, such as using renewable electricity for electrolysis and CO2 reduction. Additionally, measures like research and development funding, tax incentives, and subsidies can reduce initial investment and operational costs for companies, motivating them to adopt ECR technology. The establishment of cross-industry collaboration and information-sharing platforms will further promote the application of ECR technology. Cooperation among industries can facilitate technological integration and achieve win-win scenarios, while information platforms can enhance communication among enterprises, research institutions, and policymakers, sharing technological advancements and market dynamics. Furthermore, global cooperation and increased public awareness will create a favorable environment for the promotion of ECR technology, accelerating its commercialization and achieving sustainable development goals. 6 Conclusions and perspectives 6.1 Conclusions We have systematically classified and analyzed the research status and reaction mechanism of catalysts for electrocatalytic CO2 reduction to produce methanol, acetic acid, ethanol, and C3 Oxys. Overall, the performance of catalysts produced through ECR is often difficult to balance high selectivity and high current density. Most works that achieve over 80% selectivity for a single Oxys are measured at current densities below 20 mA cm−2. Copper and its derived materials account for the vast majority of catalysts capable of selectively producing these Oxys, but there are also a few non-Cu based materials that exhibit high selectivity towards Oxys after appropriate electronic structure tuning. In the realm of reaction mechanisms, the selective production of Oxys presents not only the traditional difficulties associated with ECR, such as the elevated activation energy of CO2 and the competing HER, but also grapples with the thermodynamically more favorable pathway for hydrocarbon generation. It is imperative to meticulously regulate reaction pathways to prevent complete deoxygenation in order to enhance the selectivity of Oxys. Consequently, it is imperative to fine-tune the regulation of oxygen-containing intermediate adsorption behavior and enhance the asymmetric CC coupling process through geometric and electronic structure modulation of electrocatalysts, adjustment of operational parameters and regulation of system configurations. 6.2 Perspectives 6.2.1 Reveal the true reaction path and provide accurate theoretical predictions Currently, DFT calculations based on intermediate adsorption energy and Gibbs free energy dominate the theoretical analysis of ECR. However, DFT typically relies on simplified and static periodic boundary conditions, which overlook the influence of external environmental factors. This limitation can lead to deviations from real reaction scenarios and does not provide direct kinetic information about the reaction process, resulting in inaccurate predictions of energy and structure. Future theoretical research should aim to establish a more accurate model that captures the complex reaction surface and interface processes under realistic conditions. This model should consider the effects of catalyst morphology, kinetic barriers, and solvent interactions to enhance our understanding of the electrocatalytic mechanisms, thereby promoting the design of catalysts and optimizing key intermediate reaction pathways. The integration of multidisciplinary research is expected to accelerate ECR development, such as machine learning (ML), which shows great potential in revealing reaction mechanisms, predicting and screening high-performance catalysts. Specifically, it can analyze large amounts of experimental and computational chemical data to extract potential reaction pathways and mechanisms, and identify relationships between reactants, intermediates, and products. Accelerate understanding of complex mechanisms by rapidly assessing numerous reaction conditions. ML models can predict the catalytic properties of new materials based on existing data and guide the design of high-performance catalysts by identifying key features that affect performance. In addition, ML facilitates high-throughput screening, evaluation of numerous catalyst candidates, and optimization of their composition, morphology, and operating parameters to improve activity, selectivity, and stability. The interdisciplinary integration of ML with materials science and chemistry has driven innovation and breakthroughs in catalyst science. Overall, ML provides a powerful tool for elucidating reaction mechanisms and predicting high-performance catalysts, greatly accelerating scientific progress, reducing experimental costs, and improving research efficiency, which is critical to advancing green chemistry and sustainable energy technologies. Of course, the above theoretical research must be supplemented by precise and time-resolved spectroscopic characterizations, including in-situ Raman, in-situ FTIR, XAS, XPS, and isotopic labelling. This combination provides important insights into ECR process, such as precise changes in catalyst compositions, structures, adsorption intermediates, and the origin of products. 6.2.2 Improve energy efficiency The economic viability of industrial CO2 electrical conversion relies not only on the selectivity and production rate of the target products but also on EE. While recent research related to ECR has begun to emphasize energy efficiency, the performance of electrolyzers remains inadequate for widespread deployment. One promising approach involves the use of zero-gap membrane electrodes, which eliminate the liquid electrolyte between the electrodes, significantly reducing internal resistance. This innovation is expected to enhance current density, battery voltage, and energy efficiency to meet industry standards. 6.2.3 Industrialization of electrocatalytic CO2 reduction The key performance indicators for industrially relevant CO2 electrolysis require a current density exceeding 200 mA cm−2, a stack energy efficiency of up to 75%, and a lifetime of up to 50,000 h [246]. In recent years, some studies have achieved the necessary current densities (300 mA cm−2 or even 1 A cm−2) [247] and high selectivity (>90%) for simple products such as CO, HCOOH, and CH4 [248]. Since the 2010, both small startups and large corporations have developed several pilot-scale ECR systems targeting products like CO, formic acid, and ethylene [249]. Notable examples include Carbon Energy Technology, which showcased a stack with a 2500 cm2 active area for CO2 electroreduction to syngas, achieving CO selectivity between 30% and 95%. Stability was demonstrated at 100 mA cm−2 for 2000 h, with a cell voltage of 2.7–3.0 V [250]. Another example is the work reported by Shu Ping Lau et al., where ethylene production via ECR achieved a FE of 50% under a total current of 10 A, maintaining stability for 1000 h [223]. However, the performance of deeply reduced oxygenated liquid products documented in the existing literature is generally below these benchmarks. It is worth noting that these results were obtained in both alkaline and neutral media. Alkaline and neutral media have inherent shortcomings, such as carbon loss and salting out, which reduce the efficiency and lifetime of the catalyst, thus affecting the overall reaction performance. In contrast, acidic or pure water systems are believed to effectively inhibit carbonate formation, thereby reducing carbon loss and enhancing catalyst stability. Therefore, designing and developing catalysts that exhibit high activity, selectivity, and stability under acidic or pure water conditions is particularly critical. This strategy has the potential to address the challenges associated with low stability and offers a promising path to improving the efficiency of ECR, contributing to its commercial viability. Overall, the industrialization of electrocatalytic CO2 reduction to produce Oxys depends on innovative catalyst design, in-depth mechanism research, and optimization of reaction conditions. By combining chemistry, materials science, computational science, and engineering with machine learning to optimize catalyst design, improve reaction efficiency, and reduce costs, we can look forward to achieving more efficient, economical and environmentally friendly CO2 conversion technologies, driving sustainable development of energy and chemical production. Jiapeng Ji is an assistant researcher at the Shenzhen Institute of Advanced Technology, Chinese Academy of Sciences. He obtained his Ph.D. in Chemical Engineering and Technology from Zhejiang University in 2021. From 2021 to 2023, he worked as a postdoctoral researcher at the Institute of Solid State Physics, Hefei Institutes of Physical Science, Chinese Academy of Sciences. His primary research focuses on the design and synthesis of atomically dispersed materials and the electrocatalytic conversion of small molecules, including water splitting and carbon dioxide reduction. Junnan Chen is currently a PhD student under the supervision of Prof. Hui-Ming Cheng and Associate Prof. Xiaolong Zhang at Shenzhen Institute of Advanced technology, Chinese Academy of Sciences (CAS). He received his MS degree from School of Chemical Engineering and Technology, Sun Yat-sen University in 2022. He focuses on the design of MOF-based materials for applications in electrochemical CO2 reduction. Juxia Xiong received her PhD from South China University of Technology in 2021 and did postdoctoral research at Shenzhen Institute of Advanced Technology, Chinese Academy of Sciences in 2022. Her research interests are mainly electricity/thermal co-catalyzed CO2 reduction. Xiaolong Zhang received his PhD from Monash University under the supervision of Prof. Jie Zhang and Prof. Alan Bond in 2019. Then, he joined the Institute of Organic Chemistry at University of Münster, where he was a Postdoctoral Fellow supported by the Humboldt foundation in the group of Prof. Frank Glorius. Now, he is an Associated Professor at Shenzhen Institute of Advanced Technology. His research interests include CO2 conversion, biomass upgrade conversion, and the utilization of other carbon resources. Hui-Ming Cheng is the director of both the Advanced Carbon Research Division of Shenyang National Laboratory for Materials Science, Institute of Metal Research, CAS since 2001, and the Institute of Technology for Carbon Neutrality, Shenzhen Institute of Advanced Technology, CAS since 2021. He is a member of CAS and a fellow of TWAS. His research activities mainly focus on energy materials and devices, carbon nanotubes, graphene, and other 2D materials. He published over 800 papers with an h-index of 158, and is a Highly Cited Researcher in three fields of materials science, chemistry, and environment and ecology. He has given over 230 plenary/keynote/invited lectures at various conferences, and won a few domestic and international awards. He is the founding Editor-in-Chief of Energy Storage Materials and has spun off several high-tech companies.

coredata.dc:description: Electrocatalytic CO2 reduction (ECR) to produce value-added fuels and chemicals using renewable electricity is an emerging strategy to mitigate global warming and decrease reliance on fossil fuels. Among various ECR products, liquid oxygenates (Oxys) are especially attractive due to their high energy density, high safety and transportability that could be adapted to the existing infrastructure and transportation system. However, efficiently generating these highly reduced oxygen-containing products by ECR remains challenging due to the complexity of coupled proton and electron transfer processes. In recent years, in-depth studies of reaction mechanisms have advanced the design of catalysts and the regulation of reaction systems for ECR to produce Oxys. Here, by focusing on the production of typical Oxys, such as methanol, acetic acid, ethanol, acetone, n-propanol, and isopropanol, we outline various reaction paths and key intermediates for the electrochemical conversion of CO2 into these target products. We also summarize the current research status and recent advances in catalysts based on their elemental composition, and consider recent studies on the change of catalyst geometry and electronic structure, as well as the optimization of reaction systems to increase ECR performance. Finally, we analyze the challenges in the field of ECR to Oxys and provide an outlook on future directions for high-efficiency catalyst prediction and design, as well as the development of advanced reaction systems.
